msContents.summary: The typescript represents an early version of 'Et les chiens se taisaient.' Unlike the versions which followed, this one dramatizes events in the Haitian Revolution, making it a Historical Drama. The story centers around the life and death of Toussaint Louverture, The Rebel of later versions. The order of the speeches is substantially different than later versions, allowing for the chronological unfolding of events, more or less matching the historical record.

support.p: At least four different kinds of paper can be identified: The first kind (atamoya) is thin, of a yellowing white hue (21.6 x 28 cm). This paper usually is typewritten directly. The second kind of paper (batata) is thin and pink (21.6 x 27.8 cm). The twenty leaves made of this kind of paper can be found solely towards the beginning of the play. All script in this kind of paper is blue carbon copy. The third kind is white with a light blue tint (21 x 27 cm). The third (coco) and the fourth (durian) kind of paper are intermingled with the first kind of paper throughout the whole work in no predictable pattern and on first sight do not indicate any special kind of relation to the use of carbon paper, sometimes revealing the marks of blue carbon paper, sometimes black, and sometimes no carbon paper at all. The fourth (durian) and final kind of paper is thick white and is also yellowing, at times with rough-hewn borders, indicating the leaves came from a larger piece of paper. (22.4 x 28 et 21.6 x 28 cm)

foliation.p: The pagination which gives the document its current coherence can be found mostly on the top center of each page written in blue ink. It begins right after the title page, and it runs continuously from page 1 to 107. Sometimes the number is written over an earlier number. Page 1 is numbered on the top right corner.

Acte II and III both have typewritten paginations in the top left corner. Numbers ranging from 3 to 19 can be found in Acte II, and from 2 to 18 in Acte III. We may infer that these paginations date to the time of drafting. The sequences are not complete in either of the acts and are not necessarily adjacent. Because the sequences restart with the acts, there's a possibility the acts were meant to be paginated independently. Another possibility is that Acte II and III may have been envisioned as beginnings. This last hypothesis makes sense in the light of the first published version, which begins roughly in Acte III of the typescript.
Present in Acte I only, there is a pencil pagination on the top-right corner which goes sequentially and uninterrupted from 3 to 23. This pagination starts on page 2 of the current pagination.

Another pencil pagination in Acte I begins on page 23 of the current pagination. The handwriting used for this pagination is different than Césaire's usual handwriting. The pagination can be found on the top left, very close to the corner.

Written in light pencil on the top-right, this is perhaps the longest running, alternative pagination deviating substantially from the main pagination. This pagination is present in Acte II and Acte III only, and like its typewritten cousin, it is incomplete and recommences in Acte III. In Acte II the numbers range from 1 to 26 ; in Acte III the numbers range from 3 to 24.

Present only in Acte II, we can find a dark pencil pagination running from 1 to 19. This pagination begins on the page marked 48-49 of the current pagination and is usually written on top of early_c. Page 8 and 10 are missing.

On page 58 of the current pagination begins a pagination written in the same blue ink, top center, starting with the number 57. This pagination is the closest to the final one. At some points Césaire just corrects one digit, at others he erases the whole number and writes the final pagination next to it. The pagination runs mostly uninterrupted until the number 103, which falls on the last page of the current pagination.

Three pages are marked with red pencil on the top-right corner. Two of these, 46 and 56 correspond to the current scheme. These pages are lacking the normal blue ink pagination. The third one is marked 48 and Césaire corrects it to the current 57 with blue ink.
Beginning on page 70 of the current pagination, three pages are marked 41', 41'' and 41''' sequentially. This is a strange occurrence and has no equivalent in the rest of the typescript.

The foliation assigned by the Bibliothèque Municipale de Saint-Dié des Vosges is written in pencil in the top-right corner. Beginning with the title page, the numbers go from 39 to 145, uninterruptedly.

condition.p: The white leaves are starting to yellow from age. Except for the thick ones, the leaves show sign of wear and tear on the edges and corners.

layoutDesc.p: The name of the speakers are usually centered on the page. The dialogue is mostly aligned left with a first-line indent for prose and irregular indent for poetry.

handDesc.handNote: Most corrections and additions in the text are done with a light blue ink. The handwriting is unmistakably Césaire's. The main pagination is also written with this ink, suggesting that the changes and additions in this medium came when the bulk of the typescript was nearing its current form.

Relatively scarce, some pages show corrections done with a darker, softer pencil. In one instance this darker pencil is used over the more common light blue ink, suggesting that this pencil was used at the latest stages.
Markings with a thin red pen can be found scattered through out Acte II. Also in Césaire's handwriting.

The second most common corrections and additions in the text are written in lead pencil. Two kinds of lead pencil can be identified, a light and a dark one. Sometimes it is difficult to tell them apart. These markings are present throughout the texts, although they start becoming scarcer as the text nears the end. The light pencil can be said to precede the dark pencil for the most part. This is evident in cases where the dark pencil is used above the light one, and in the cases where pagination written with the light pencil are superceded by pagination written with the dark. This seems to suggest that Césaire used this pencil at the earliest stages of revision.
A few pages have markings with a bright red pencil.
There are several markings which are hard to identify. They seem to be made with a dark black pen.

typeDesc.typeNote: The bulk of the text is typewritten in a Serif font typical of old typewriters. Most of the typewritten text, if not all, is carbon copy. In several places, specially towards the end, because of the lack of visible carbon residue, there is a possibility that we have original type. Both blue and black carbon paper residue can be clearly identified in the rest of the text.

additions.p: The title page includes an entry from the cataloguer at Sait-Dié marking the contents of the folder, "107 ff + lettre."
Strange pencil markings dot page 72 of the current pagination. They are smudged beyond recognition.

sealDesc.p: The seal of the Bibliothèque Municipale de Saint-Dié des Vosges is present in every page towards the bottom. The seal is in the shape of a circle with the letters S and D separated by a Patriarchal cross.

origin.p: The most precise information about the completion of the typescript during the War period can be found in the correspondence between Césaire and Breton housed at the Bibliothèque Littéraire Jacques Doucet. The first of these letters which mentions the play is dated September 23, 1943, where Césaire notes he has just finished a "drame nègre." Correspondance adressée à André Breton (BRT.C.446), le 22 septembre 1943. Bibliothèque Littéraire Jacques Doucet, fonds André Breton. Since Césaire never left Martinique during the early war period, it is fair to assume that the typescript was composed there.

provenance.p: A letter dated November 16, 1943 announces the impending arrival in New York of a package containing "un recueil possible de poèmes ainsi qu’un drame: Et les chiens se taisaient." Correspondance adressée à André Breton (BRT.C.447), le 16 novembre 1943. Bibliothèque Littérature Jacques Doucet, fonds André Breton. Two months later, Césaire will send Breton "quelques pages supplémentaires," Correspondance adressée à André Breton (BRT.C.448), le 17 janvier 1944. Bibliothèque Littéraire Jacques Doucet, fonds André Breton. consisting of a text entitled Intermède, which later became part of the published version, and for which we find no trace in the typescript, suggesting that at this date, Yvan Goll, the Franco-German poet, who was at the time working on the English translation of the Cahier d'un retour au pays natal, already had the typescript in his possession.

In a series of letters to Breton in 1944, Césaire disavows the text and asks Breton to retrieve it from Goll. In a letter from Breton to Goll dated December 12, 1944, Breton asks zhim, for what seems to be the last time, to return "le complément des manuscrits de Césaire : Et les chiens se taisaient" Correspondance adressée à Yvan Goll. Fonds Yvan et Claire Goll, Bibliothèque Municipale de Saint-Dié des Vosges, n° 510.513 (dossier A. Breton). . Goll never complied, bringing the text with him to Saint-Dié des Vosges after the end of the war.

history.acquisition: The typescript was finally bequeathed to the Bibliothèque Municipale de Saint-Dié des Vosges, along with the rest of the Goll papers, after Goll's widow, Claire, passed away in 1977. The original curator of the collection, Albert Ronsin, was the first to call attention to the existence of the typescript in his article Yvan Goll et André Breton: des relations difficiles published in 1994.

segmentation.p: The anonymous block element, ab, has been chosen to represent the myriad line and paragraph forms in the text. The lineation of the play is hardly consistent, and irregular lines are the rule rather than the exception. The anonymous block element preserves the original line structure without making any interpretations.

correction.p: Overprints have been processed silently wherever they are irrelevant, clear and unambiguous. In most of these cases, the typist just stroke over the mistake several times to make the correct letter stand out.

Whenever an addition has been tagged within a substitution with @place="inline" it means the addition has been written over the characters tagged for deletion. In order to avoid redundancy, no rend is offered for the del.
Whenever a deletion is marked @rend="overprint" this means the typist has typed over the characters using either the letter 'x' or the hyphen '-'.

Whenever a correction has been made to a faded character by writing over it this is marked within an add tag as a @type="clarification". In most of these cases the subst and del have been avoided. In some rare exceptions, these have been included to mark an anomaly.
Unique, unexplainable errors have been preserved under sic tags, even if the intentions are clear. In all cases, though, the correct rendering is offered as a choice.

In several instances, corrections in one medium are emphasized with a darker media written over it. Most of these cases consist of blue ink or darker pencil written over light pencil markings. These occurences are signaled with a @status=double. The @hand used in these tags refers to the lowermost layer to indicate when the deletion was originally made. A note has been added for deviations from the norm.
Whenever a diacritical mark has been added without any further alterations of the text, the addition is marked as @type="accent".

normalization.p: Where appropriate the character î has been substituted for ï silently.

The typewriter used in the production of the typescript did not have a character for 'œ' and instead marked the letter using the two letters 'oe'. In our version, the 'œ' has been recuperated where appropriate.

Punctuation-related whitespace has been normalized to comform with modern French usage. The typescript is inconsistent in this regard, ommiting the spaces in some places and following the norm in others. We have marked corrections where the space is added as <corr><space/></corr> and corrections where the space is deleted as <corr><del><space/></del></corr>

hyphenation.p: The typescript contains rare end of line hyphenations.

refsDecl.p: For the most part we take as our main reference point the main pagination "Page". Page breaks effectively divide the document according to this scheme. Note that one of the pages is marked 48-49 to conform with Césaire's own numeration. This does not affect the order of the scheme since references are absolute, not numerical.

Mesdames et Messieurs, suivez-moi bien... En 1793 nous apprenions qu'au
nom des droits de l'homme, nous apprenions dis-je que la plus vile de toutes
les races allait s'asseoir côte à côte avec nous au banquet d'une risible frate­
ternité.

Ah, le résultat ne se fit guère attendre. Il y eut du comique. Il y eut
du tragique. Il y eut de l'horrible. On vit des cannibales entrer gonflés d'or
gueil dans les villes prises ; on en vit aux Te Deum. On en vit rédiger des
constitutions. Voilà ce que l'on vit , bonnes gens qui m'écoutez. Et ce que
l'on vit encore, la fumée dans le ciel de midi, le feu dans le ciel de minuit
d'innombrables aurores boréales jetant au loin le reflet du crime et de l'ab
surdité.

Hé bien, je dis qu'il est une justice suprème, et c'est elle qui refait au
jourd'hui du général Toussaint Louverture, le vieux Toussaint, l'esclave Tous
saint, triste chose oubliée aux latrines de l'histoire, un nègre pouilleux,
un nègre dégringolé...
